passageHtml: Threatened species are plants and animals that are __________ become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range. According to the former Attorney General Loretta Lynch, "We all have a responsibility to protect endangered species, both for their sake and for the sake of our own future generations."
passageText: Threatened species are plants and animals that are __________ become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range. According to the former Attorney General Loretta Lynch, "We all have a responsibility to protect endangered species, both for their sake and for the sake of our own future generations."
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

A.html:
A
definitely going to
A

B.html:
B
inevitably bound to
B

C.html:
C
probably able to
C

D.html:
D
likely to
D

explanation: D. Choice D, likely to, is the most logical phrase to fit in the blank in the sentence. Choices A and B are illogical because these species are threatened, which indicates that their becoming endangered isn't definite or inevitable. Choice C is incorrect because probably able to suggests the species have some say in the matter, which they don't.
fullHtml: Threatened species are plants and animals that are __________ become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range. According to the former Attorney General Loretta Lynch, "We all have a responsibility to protect endangered species, both for their sake and for the sake of our own future generations."
fullText: Threatened species are plants and animals that are __________ become endangered within the foreseeable future throughout all or a significant portion of its range. According to the former Attorney General Loretta Lynch, "We all have a responsibility to protect endangered species, both for their sake and for the sake of our own future generations." Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

passageHtml: It is important for clinical trials to have participants of __________ ages, sexes, races, and ethnicities. When research involves a group of people who are similar, the findings may not apply to or benefit everyone.
passageText: It is important for clinical trials to have participants of __________ ages, sexes, races, and ethnicities. When research involves a group of people who are similar, the findings may not apply to or benefit everyone.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

A.html:
A
consistent
A

B.html:
B
different
B

C.html:
C
similar
C

D.html:
D
conflicting
D

explanation: B. The best word to fill in the blank is different because the sentence states that choosing people who are similar won't yield accurate or beneficial results. Choices A and C are both words that mean the opposite of what the text states. Choice D isn't logical because conflicting ages doesn't make sense.
fullHtml: It is important for clinical trials to have participants of __________ ages, sexes, races, and ethnicities. When research involves a group of people who are similar, the findings may not apply to or benefit everyone.
fullText: It is important for clinical trials to have participants of __________ ages, sexes, races, and ethnicities. When research involves a group of people who are similar, the findings may not apply to or benefit everyone. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

passageHtml: Hurricanes Irma and Maria highlighted the challenges for Federal agencies that rely on residential addresses to supply services in Puerto Rico. Relief efforts during the 2017 hurricane season were __________ by the absence of an island-wide system of addressing and the lack of physical addresses for approximately one-third of the island.
passageText: Hurricanes Irma and Maria highlighted the challenges for Federal agencies that rely on residential addresses to supply services in Puerto Rico. Relief efforts during the 2017 hurricane season were __________ by the absence of an island-wide system of addressing and the lack of physical addresses for approximately one-third of the island.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
hampered
A

B.html:
B
assisted
B

C.html:
C
enhanced
C

D.html:
D
enlightened
D

explanation: A. Choice A, hampered, means hindered or impeded by, so it logically fits into the blank. It makes sense that the absence of a system of addressing would impede efforts to supply services. None of the other choices have the negative connotation of hampered.
fullHtml: Hurricanes Irma and Maria highlighted the challenges for Federal agencies that rely on residential addresses to supply services in Puerto Rico. Relief efforts during the 2017 hurricane season were __________ by the absence of an island-wide system of addressing and the lack of physical addresses for approximately one-third of the island.

passageHtml:
The following excerpt is adapted from A Short History of the World by H. G. Wells (1922).

The telescope reveals to us in various parts of the heavens luminous spiral clouds of matter, the spiral nebula, which appear to be in rotation about a center. It is __________ by many astronomers that the Sun and its planets were once such a spiral, and that their matter has undergone concentration into its present form.
passageText: The following excerpt is adapted from A Short History of the World by H. G. Wells (1922).The telescope reveals to us in various parts of the heavens luminous spiral clouds of matter, the spiral nebula, which appear to be in rotation about a center. It is __________ by many astronomers that the Sun and its planets were once such a spiral, and that their matter has undergone concentration into its present form.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
ordered
A

B.html:
B
supposed
B

C.html:
C
undermined
C

D.html:
D
required
D

explanation: B. Choice B, supposed is the best word to fill in the blank because the astronomers don't know for sure that the Sun and its planets were once in such a spiral. Supposed means generally assumed or believed to be the case. None of the other choices make sense in the sentence.
fullHtml:

passageHtml: The rapidly rising river was another element of danger. It was a fearful sight to see the __________ flood plunging by, bearing great trees and logs of driftwood on its muddy surface many feet above the ground.
passageText: The rapidly rising river was another element of danger. It was a fearful sight to see the __________ flood plunging by, bearing great trees and logs of driftwood on its muddy surface many feet above the ground.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
deceitful
A

B.html:
B
placid
B

C.html:
C
sluggish
C

D.html:
D
relentless
D

explanation: D. All the evidence in the sentence points to Choice D, relentless, which means nonstop or incessant. It is the best word to describe a river that is rapidly rising and a flood plunging by carrying trees and logs. Choices B and C are the opposite of relentless and Choice A, deceitful, is illogical.
fullHtml: The rapidly rising river was another element of danger. It was a fearful sight to see the __________ flood plunging by, bearing great trees and logs of driftwood on its muddy surface many feet above the ground.

passageHtml: The Box Tree Moth is invasive pest can significantly damage and potentially kill boxwood (Buxus species) plants if left unchecked. The insect is native to East Asia and has become a serious invasive pest in Europe, where it continues to spread. The caterpillars feed mostly on boxwood, and heavy infestations can __________ host plants. Once the leaves are gone, larvae consume the bark, leading to plant death.
passageText: The Box Tree Moth is invasive pest can significantly damage and potentially kill boxwood (Buxus species) plants if left unchecked. The insect is native to East Asia and has become a serious invasive pest in Europe, where it continues to spread. The caterpillars feed mostly on boxwood, and heavy infestations can __________ host plants. Once the leaves are gone, larvae consume the bark, leading to plant death.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
defoliate
A

B.html:
B
embark
B

C.html:
C
empower
C

D.html:
D
engender
D

explanation: A. The context clues in the sentence (the leaves are gone, larvae consume the bark) lead to Choice A, defoliate, which means to remove the leaves from a plant. The other choices, embark (to begin), empower (to give power), and engender (to give rise to), do not make sense in the context of the passage.
fullHtml: The Box Tree Moth is invasive pest can significantly damage and potentially kill boxwood (Buxus species) plants if left unchecked. The insect is native to East Asia and has become a serious invasive pest in Europe, where it continues to spread. The caterpillars feed mostly on boxwood, and heavy infestations can __________ host plants. Once the leaves are gone, larvae consume the bark, leading to plant death.

passageHtml: Non-chronological storytelling is not new to modern novels and films; in the Odyssey, for example, Homer uses flashbacks to __________ earlier scenes in Odysseus' adventures.
passageText: Non-chronological storytelling is not new to modern novels and films; in the Odyssey, for example, Homer uses flashbacks to __________ earlier scenes in Odysseus' adventures.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
recount
A

B.html:
B
reuse
B

C.html:
C
reinstate
C

D.html:
D
rescind
D

explanation: A. Choice A, recount, means to tell or give an account of something. It is the logical choice to fill in the blank in a sentence about Homer using flashbacks in his storytelling. The other choices, reuse (to use again), reinstate (to put back into a position), and rescind (to take back what was previously given) are not logical in this sentence.
fullHtml: Non-chronological storytelling is not new to modern novels and films; in the Odyssey, for example, Homer uses flashbacks to __________ earlier scenes in Odysseus' adventures.
fullText: Non-chronological storytelling is not new to modern novels and films; in the Odyssey, for example, Homer uses flashbacks to __________ earlier scenes in Odysseus' adventures. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

passageHtml:
The following passage is adapted from an article on the USGS Volcano Hazards Program website.

USGS scientists monitor over 160 active and potentially active volcanoes in the United States. Most of these volcanoes are located in Alaska, a state where eruptions occur almost every year. The rest of the volcanoes are located throughout the American West, and in Hawaii. Since there are on average between 50 and 60 volcanoes that erupt each year somewhere on Earth (about one every week), some of Earth's volcanoes may actually erupt within a few days or hours of each other, possibly suggesting a cause-and-effect relationship between eruptions. Upon closer inspection, however, the eruptions are almost always preceded by very different build-up periods in terms of time (days to weeks to months to years) and type of activity (earthquakes, ground deformation, gas emissions, and small eruptions).
passageText: The following passage is adapted from an article on the USGS Volcano Hazards Program website.USGS scientists monitor over 160 active and potentially active volcanoes in the United States. Most of these volcanoes are located in Alaska, a state where eruptions occur almost every year. The rest of the volcanoes are located throughout the American West, and in Hawaii. Since there are on average between 50 and 60 volcanoes that erupt each year somewhere on Earth (about one every week), some of Earth's volcanoes may actually erupt within a few days or hours of each other, possibly suggesting a cause-and-effect relationship between eruptions. Upon closer inspection, however, the eruptions are almost always preceded by very different build-up periods in terms of time (days to weeks to months to years) and type of activity (earthquakes, ground deformation, gas emissions, and small eruptions).
questionText: Which choice best describes the function of the last sentence in the overall structure of the text?

A.text: It states a hypothesis that is contradicted by evidence provided earlier in the text.
A.html:
A
It states a hypothesis that is contradicted by evidence provided earlier in the text.
A

B.text: It presents a generalization that is exemplified by the discussion of the volcanoes in Hawaii.
B.html:
B
It presents a generalization that is exemplified by the discussion of the volcanoes in Hawaii.
B

C.text: It offers an alternative explanation to a speculative relationship referred to earlier in the text.
C.html:
C
It offers an alternative explanation to a speculative relationship referred to earlier in the text.
C

D.text: It provides context that clarifies why volcanoes are preceded by different build-up periods.
D.html:
D
It provides context that clarifies why volcanoes are preceded by different build-up periods.
D

explanation: C. The underlined sentence offers an alternative explanation (eruptions are preceded by different build-up periods) to a speculative relationship (possibly suggesting a cause-and-effect relationship) referred to earlier in the text. The underlined sentence doesn't state a hypothesis that is contradicted by evidence (Choice A) or present a generalization that is exemplified by the discussion of the volcanoes (Choice B). It also doesn't clarify WHY volcanoes are preceded by different build-up periods (Choice D).
fullHtml:
The following passage is adapted from an article on the USGS Volcano Hazards Program website.

USGS scientists monitor over 160 active and potentially active volcanoes in the United States. Most of these volcanoes are located in Alaska, a state where eruptions occur almost every year. The rest of the volcanoes are located throughout the American West, and in Hawaii. Since there are on average between 50 and 60 volcanoes that erupt each year somewhere on Earth (about one every week), some of Earth's volcanoes may actually erupt within a few days or hours of each other, possibly suggesting a cause-and-effect relationship between eruptions. Upon closer inspection, however, the eruptions are almost always preceded by very different build-up periods in terms of time (days to weeks to months to years) and type of activity (earthquakes, ground deformation, gas emissions, and small eruptions).

Upon closer inspection, however, the eruptions are almost always preceded by very different build-up periods in terms of time (days to weeks to months to years) and type of activity (earthquakes, ground deformation, gas emissions, and small eruptions). passageHtml:
The following is an excerpt from a National Institutes of Health article titled "Genetics."

All living things evolved from a common ancestor. Therefore, humans, animals, and other organisms share many of the same genes, and the molecules made from them function in similar ways.

Scientists have found many genes that have been preserved through millions of years of evolution and are present in a range of organisms living today. They can study these preserved genes and compare the genomes of different species to uncover similarities and differences that improve their understanding of how human genes function and are controlled. This knowledge helps researchers develop new strategies to treat and prevent human disease. Scientists also study the genes of bacteria, viruses, and fungi for solutions to prevent or treat infection. Increasingly, these studies are offering insight into how microbes on and in the body affect our health, sometimes in beneficial ways.
passageText: The following is an excerpt from a National Institutes of Health article titled "Genetics."All living things evolved from a common ancestor. Therefore, humans, animals, and other organisms share many of the same genes, and the molecules made from them function in similar ways.Scientists have found many genes that have been preserved through millions of years of evolution and are present in a range of organisms living today. They can study these preserved genes and compare the genomes of different species to uncover similarities and differences that improve their understanding of how human genes function and are controlled. This knowledge helps researchers develop new strategies to treat and prevent human disease. Scientists also study the genes of bacteria, viruses, and fungi for solutions to prevent or treat infection. Increasingly, these studies are offering insight into how microbes on and in the body affect our health, sometimes in beneficial ways. Which choice poses a question that can be answered by the information in the text?
questionText: The following is an excerpt from a National Institutes of Health article titled "Genetics."All living things evolved from a common ancestor. Therefore, humans, animals, and other organisms share many of the same genes, and the molecules made from them function in similar ways.Scientists have found many genes that have been preserved through millions of years of evolution and are present in a range of organisms living today. They can study these preserved genes and compare the genomes of different species to uncover similarities and differences that improve their understanding of how human genes function and are controlled. This knowledge helps researchers develop new strategies to treat and prevent human disease. Scientists also study the genes of bacteria, viruses, and fungi for solutions to prevent or treat infection. Increasingly, these studies are offering insight into how microbes on and in the body affect our health, sometimes in beneficial ways. Which choice poses a question that can be answered by the information in the text?

A.text: Why do scientists study the genes of organisms other than human beings?
A.html:
A
Why do scientists study the genes of organisms other than human beings?
A

B.text: What genes do humans share with bacteria, fungi, and viruses?
B.html:
B
What genes do humans share with bacteria, fungi, and viruses?
B

C.text: How do genes function to treat and prevent human disease?
C.html:
C
How do genes function to treat and prevent human disease?
C

D.text: How do researchers preserve the genes of organisms that no longer exist today?
D.html:
D
How do researchers preserve the genes of organisms that no longer exist today?
D

explanation: A. Of the four questions in the choices, only Choice A, Why do scientists study the genes of organisms other than human beings? can be answered by the information in the text. The questions in Choices B, C, and D cannot be answered by the information in the text.

All living things evolved from a common ancestor. Therefore, humans, animals, and other organisms share many of the same genes, and the molecules made from them function in similar ways.

Scientists have found many genes that have been preserved through millions of years of evolution and are present in a range of organisms living today. passageHtml: To get a grasp of the complex interactions between living things, we can start by looking at a simple linear food chain: sun, dandelion, rabbit, and hawk. Sunlight is converted into chemical energy by green plants. Part of that energy is captured by herbivorous insects and vertebrates when they eat the plants. Carnivores then eat herbivores. In reality, however, the flow of energy through an ecosystem is more like a web. Species share energy back and forth in subtle ways. If we consider other relationships (for example, plants that provide cover and nesting habitats to animals; insects, birds, and bats that pollinate flowers; rodents that disperse seeds; animals that require shade created by plants; and so on), our web approaches a symbol of what nature is really like.
passageText: To get a grasp of the complex interactions between living things, we can start by looking at a simple linear food chain: sun, dandelion, rabbit, and hawk. Sunlight is converted into chemical energy by green plants. Part of that energy is captured by herbivorous insects and vertebrates when they eat the plants. Carnivores then eat herbivores. In reality, however, the flow of energy through an ecosystem is more like a web. Species share energy back and forth in subtle ways. If we consider other relationships (for example, plants that provide cover and nesting habitats to animals; insects, birds, and bats that pollinate flowers; rodents that disperse seeds; animals that require shade created by plants; and so on), our web approaches a symbol of what nature is really like. Which choice best explains the difference between a linear and a web-like representation of the food chain?
questionText: To get a grasp of the complex interactions between living things, we can start by looking at a simple linear food chain: sun, dandelion, rabbit, and hawk. Sunlight is converted into chemical energy by green plants. Part of that energy is captured by herbivorous insects and vertebrates when they eat the plants. Carnivores then eat herbivores. In reality, however, the flow of energy through an ecosystem is more like a web. Species share energy back and forth in subtle ways. If we consider other relationships (for example, plants that provide cover and nesting habitats to animals; insects, birds, and bats that pollinate flowers; rodents that disperse seeds; animals that require shade created by plants; and so on), our web approaches a symbol of what nature is really like. Which choice best explains the difference between a linear and a web-like representation of the food chain?

A.text: A linear representation expresses a more complex relationship while a web representation expresses a simpler relationship.
A.html:
A
A linear representation expresses a more complex relationship while a web representation expresses a simpler relationship.
A

B.text: A linear representation expresses an inorganic relationship while a web representation expresses an organic relationship.
B.html:
B
A linear representation expresses an inorganic relationship while a web representation expresses an organic relationship.
B

C.text: A linear representation expresses a non-human relationship while a web representation expresses a human-to-human relationship.
C.html:
C
A linear representation expresses a non-human relationship while a web representation expresses a human-to-human relationship.
C

D.text: A linear representation expresses a relationship in a straight line while a web representation expresses a multi-directional relationship.
D.html:
D
A linear representation expresses a relationship in a straight line while a web representation expresses a multi-directional relationship.
D

explanation: D. Choice D is the best explanation of the difference between a linear and a web-like representation of the food chain. As the text implies, the linear relationship is a straight line; for example, the sun provides energy to the dandelion; the dandelion provides food for the rabbit; the rabbit is food for the hawk. In a web-like system, energy flows in multiple directions, not simply in a straight line. Choice A is inaccurate; a linear representation is less complex than a web-like representation. Choice B is incorrect because the representations have nothing to do with inorganic versus organic relationships. Choice C is incorrect; the difference has nothing to do with human versus non-human.
fullHtml: To get a grasp of the complex interactions between living things, we can start by looking at a simple linear food chain: sun, dandelion, rabbit, and hawk. Sunlight is converted into chemical energy by green plants. Part of that energy is captured by herbivorous insects and vertebrates when they eat the plants. Carnivores then eat herbivores. In reality, however, the flow of energy through an ecosystem is more like a web. Species share energy back and forth in subtle ways. If we consider other relationships (for example, plants that provide cover and nesting habitats to animals; insects, birds, and bats that pollinate flowers; rodents that disperse seeds; animals that require shade created by plants; and so on), our web approaches a symbol of what nature is really like.

passageHtml: The paintings of Salvador Dali, the renowned surrealist artist, are immediately recognizable for their bizarre images and technical precision. He created highly personal paintings that broke with tradition and __________ optical illusions.
passageText: The paintings of Salvador Dali, the renowned surrealist artist, are immediately recognizable for their bizarre images and technical precision. He created highly personal paintings that broke with tradition and __________ optical illusions.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
featured
A

B.html:
B
overwhelmed
B

C.html:
C
discredited
C

D.html:
D
renewed
D

explanation: A. Choice A, featured, is the best word to fit in the blank. In the context of the sentence, featured means included as an important part, and Dali included optical illusions as an important part of his paintings. Choice B is incorrect because overwhelmed is not logical in the context of the sentence. Choice C is also incorrect because nothing in the sentence suggests Dali discredited optical illusions. Choice D, renewed, also does not fit in the logic of the sentence.
fullHtml: The paintings of Salvador Dali, the renowned surrealist artist, are immediately recognizable for their bizarre images and technical precision. He created highly personal paintings that broke with tradition and __________ optical illusions.
fullText: The paintings of Salvador Dali, the renowned surrealist artist, are immediately recognizable for their bizarre images and technical precision. He created highly personal paintings that broke with tradition and __________ optical illusions. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

passageHtml: Two particularly useful __________ of the timing of spring events are the first leaf dates and the first bloom dates of two flowering plants: lilacs and honeysuckles. These plants have an easily monitored flowering season, a relatively high survival rate, and a large geographic distribution.
passageText: Two particularly useful __________ of the timing of spring events are the first leaf dates and the first bloom dates of two flowering plants: lilacs and honeysuckles. These plants have an easily monitored flowering season, a relatively high survival rate, and a large geographic distribution.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
effects
A

B.html:
B
varieties
B

C.html:
C
species
C

D.html:
D
indicators
D

explanation: D. Choice D is the best answer because it logically completes the sentence. The two flowering plants are useful indicators of the timing of spring. Choices A, B, and C are illogical; the plants aren't useful effects or varieties or species of the timing.
fullHtml: Two particularly useful __________ of the timing of spring events are the first leaf dates and the first bloom dates of two flowering plants: lilacs and honeysuckles. These plants have an easily monitored flowering season, a relatively high survival rate, and a large geographic distribution.
fullText: Two particularly useful __________ of the timing of spring events are the first leaf dates and the first bloom dates of two flowering plants: lilacs and honeysuckles. These plants have an easily monitored flowering season, a relatively high survival rate, and a large geographic distribution. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

passageHtml: Eighteenth-century stories of the strange appearance and behavior of an unidentified creature left naturalists __________ as to what could fit its seemingly catch-all characteristics. The strange animal captured the imagination of scientists who did not know how to classify the duck-billed platypus. We now know that the platypus is a monotreme, an ancient type of mammal that lays eggs.
passageText: Eighteenth-century stories of the strange appearance and behavior of an unidentified creature left naturalists __________ as to what could fit its seemingly catch-all characteristics. The strange animal captured the imagination of scientists who did not know how to classify the duck-billed platypus. We now know that the platypus is a monotreme, an ancient type of mammal that lays eggs.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
mystified
A

B.html:
B
delighted
B

C.html:
C
settled
C

D.html:
D
confident
D

explanation: A. Choice A, mystified, is the best word to fit in the blank. The unidentified creature mystified (puzzled) naturalists who did not know how to classify it. Choice B might have tempted you because it's possible the naturalists were delighted with the creature, but the context clues in the sentence (seemingly catch-all characteristics, did not know, we now know) suggest they were confused or mystified. They certainly weren't settled or confident, so Choices C and D are illogical.
fullHtml: Eighteenth-century stories of the strange appearance and behavior of an unidentified creature left naturalists __________ as to what could fit its seemingly catch-all characteristics. The strange animal captured the imagination of scientists who did not know how to classify the duck-billed platypus. We now know that the platypus is a monotreme, an ancient type of mammal that lays eggs.
fullText: Eighteenth-century stories of the strange appearance and behavior of an unidentified creature left naturalists __________ as to what could fit its seemingly catch-all characteristics. The strange animal captured the imagination of scientists who did not know how to classify the duck-billed platypus. We now know that the platypus is a monotreme, an ancient type of mammal that lays eggs. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

passageHtml: Comparative genomics is directly related to evolution because all living things share a common ancestor. By using computer tools to examine genes that have remained the same in many organisms over millions of years, researchers can __________ signals that control how genes work.
passageText: Comparative genomics is directly related to evolution because all living things share a common ancestor. By using computer tools to examine genes that have remained the same in many organisms over millions of years, researchers can __________ signals that control how genes work.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
disrupt
A

B.html:
B
locate
B

C.html:
C
question
C

D.html:
D
influence
D

explanation: B. Choice B, locate, is the best word to fill in the blank. The researchers are using computer tools to find or locate signals that control how genes work. There is no contextual evidence to suggest the researchers want to disrupt, question, or influence the signals, so Choices A, C, and D are incorrect.
fullHtml: Comparative genomics is directly related to evolution because all living things share a common ancestor. By using computer tools to examine genes that have remained the same in many organisms over millions of years, researchers can __________ signals that control how genes work.
fullText: Comparative genomics is directly related to evolution because all living things share a common ancestor. By using computer tools to examine genes that have remained the same in many organisms over millions of years, researchers can __________ signals that control how genes work. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

passageHtml: The Antiquities Act of 1906 was inspired by the need to __________ ancient American Indian ruins in the southwestern United States during the 19th-century push to open the country's western frontier. One hundred years after its enactment, the Antiquities Act remains one of the nation's most important conservation laws.
passageText: The Antiquities Act of 1906 was inspired by the need to __________ ancient American Indian ruins in the southwestern United States during the 19th-century push to open the country's western frontier. One hundred years after its enactment, the Antiquities Act remains one of the nation's most important conservation laws.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
raze
A

B.html:
B
reconfigure
B

C.html:
C
safeguard
C

D.html:
D
complete
D

explanation: C. Always use the logic of the sentence and the context clues to help you select the best word to fill in the blank. In this sentence, the logic suggests that a conservation law has been enacted to safeguard or protect ancient ruins. It certainly wouldn't attempt to raze (tear down) or reconfigure (rearrange) the ruins, so Choices A and B are incorrect. It also doesn't make sense to enact a conservation law to complete ancient ruins; then they wouldn't be ancient ruins! And, there is no context clue to suggest this action.
fullHtml: The Antiquities Act of 1906 was inspired by the need to __________ ancient American Indian ruins in the southwestern United States during the 19th-century push to open the country's western frontier. One hundred years after its enactment, the Antiquities Act remains one of the nation's most important conservation laws.
fullText: The Antiquities Act of 1906 was inspired by the need to __________ ancient American Indian ruins in the southwestern United States during the 19th-century push to open the country's western frontier. One hundred years after its enactment, the Antiquities Act remains one of the nation's most important conservation laws. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

passageHtml: The rather pedestrian plot of the film was elevated by its __________ cinematography; the magnificent panoramas of the African veldt were photographed in stunning clarity and breathtaking beauty.
passageText: The rather pedestrian plot of the film was elevated by its __________ cinematography; the magnificent panoramas of the African veldt were photographed in stunning clarity and breathtaking beauty.
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

A.html:
A
ordinary
A

B.html:
B
abundant
B

C.html:
C
exquisite
C

D.html:
D
banal
D

explanation: C. Choice C completes the text with the most logical and precise word because it conveys the elevation of the pedestrian (dull, ordinary) plot by the exquisite (gorgeous) cinematography of the film. Choices A, ordinary, and D, banal (dull or trite), are too close in meaning to pedestrian and so would not elevate the plot. Choice B, abundant, doesn't make sense: the whole film consists of cinematography.
fullHtml: The rather pedestrian plot of the film was elevated by its __________ cinematography; the magnificent panoramas of the African veldt were photographed in stunning clarity and breathtaking beauty.
fullText: The rather pedestrian plot of the film was elevated by its __________ cinematography; the magnificent panoramas of the African veldt were photographed in stunning clarity and breathtaking beauty. Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word?

passageHtml:
The following excerpt is adapted from Punch: Volume 118, Nos. 3052-3077.

"Assuredly," I said. "We don't take enough advice, in my opinion - just as we don't take enough exercise or wholesome food. It is too much the fashion to ask advice and not take it. But if we modelled our lives on the disinterested opinion of other people, and availed ourselves of the combined judgment of our fellows, the world would be both happier and wiser in many directions. And if men knew when they were invited to express an opinion that it was no mere conventional piece of civility or empty compliment which prompted us to ask their criticism, consider how they would put their best powers forward."
passageText: The following excerpt is adapted from Punch: Volume 118, Nos. 3052-3077."Assuredly," I said. "We don't take enough advice, in my opinion - just as we don't take enough exercise or wholesome food. It is too much the fashion to ask advice and not take it. But if we modelled our lives on the disinterested opinion of other people, and availed ourselves of the combined judgment of our fellows, the world would be both happier and wiser in many directions. And if men knew when they were invited to express an opinion that it was no mere conventional piece of civility or empty compliment which prompted us to ask their criticism, consider how they would put their best powers forward."
questionText: Which of the following best expresses the primary claim of the speaker in the passage?

A.text: It is far healthier to follow one's personal inclination than to accept the opinions of others.
A.html:
A
It is far healthier to follow one's personal inclination than to accept the opinions of others.
A

B.text: The primary qualities that allow society to function are civility and good judgment in interpersonal interactions.
B.html:
B
The primary qualities that allow society to function are civility and good judgment in interpersonal interactions.
B

C.text: Advice that is not requested should never be offered.
C.html:
C
Advice that is not requested should never be offered.
C

D.text: Our lives would be improved if we were to seek and heed the objective opinions of others.
D.html:
D
Our lives would be improved if we were to seek and heed the objective opinions of others.
D

explanation: D. Choice D best expresses the primary claim of the speaker. The speaker clearly states that we don't take enough advice… and we should model our lives on the disinterested opinion of other people. Based on the context, the speaker would disagree with Choices A, B, and C, none of which are stated in or implied by the text.

But if we modelled our lives on the disinterested opinion of other people, and availed ourselves of the combined judgment of our fellows, the world would be both happier and wiser in many directions. And if men knew when they were invited to express an opinion that it was no mere conventional piece of civility or empty compliment which prompted us to ask their criticism, consider how they would put their best powers forward."

And if men knew when they were invited to express an opinion that it was no mere conventional piece of civility or empty compliment which prompted us to ask their criticism, consider how they would put their best powers forward." Which of the following best expresses the primary claim of the speaker in the passage?

passageHtml:
The following excerpt is from Bedouins by James Huneker (1920).

Some years ago in Paris I saw and heard Mary Garden sing La Traviata. The singing was superlative; she then boasted a coloratura style that would surprise those who now only know her vocalization. It was, however, the conception and acting that intrigued me. Originality stamped both. The death scene was of unusual poignancy; evidently the young American had been spying upon Bernhardt and Duse.*

*Sarah Bernhardt and Eleonora Giulia Amalia Duse were famous actresses of the late 19th century.
passageText: The following excerpt is from Bedouins by James Huneker (1920).Some years ago in Paris I saw and heard Mary Garden sing La Traviata. The singing was superlative; she then boasted a coloratura style that would surprise those who now only know her vocalization. It was, however, the conception and acting that intrigued me. Originality stamped both. The death scene was of unusual poignancy; evidently the young American had been spying upon Bernhardt and Duse.**Sarah Bernhardt and Eleonora Giulia Amalia Duse were famous actresses of the late 19th century.
questionText: Which choice best states the function of the underlined sentence in the overall structure of the text?

A.text: To offer a criticism of the singer's performance
A.html:
A
To offer a criticism of the singer's performance
A

B.text: To provide objectivity to an analysis of the singer's acting ability
B.html:
B
To provide objectivity to an analysis of the singer's acting ability
B

C.text: To indicate the qualities that fascinated the writer
C.html:
C
To indicate the qualities that fascinated the writer
C

D.text: To praise the coloratura style of the singer
D.html:
D
To praise the coloratura style of the singer
D

explanation: C. Choice C best states the function of the underlined sentence in the overall structure of the text. The text describes the singing style of Mary Garden but points out that her conception and acting were qualities that most intrigued the writer. The sentence doesn't criticize the performance (Choice A) or provide an objective analysis (Choice B) or praise the coloratura style of the singer (Choice D).

The death scene was of unusual poignancy; evidently the young American had been spying upon Bernhardt and Duse.*

*Sarah Bernhardt and Eleonora Giulia Amalia Duse were famous actresses of the late 19th century.

passageHtml:
The following text is adapted from Democracy in America by Alexis de Tocqueville (1835).

The settlers who established themselves on the shores of New England all belonged to the more independent, knowledgeable, and skilled classes of their native country. Their union on the soil of America at once presented the singular phenomenon of a society containing neither lords nor common people, neither rich nor poor. These men possessed, in proportion to their number, a greater mass of intelligence than is to be found in any European nation of our own time. All, without a single exception, _________.
passageText: The following text is adapted from Democracy in America by Alexis de Tocqueville (1835).The settlers who established themselves on the shores of New England all belonged to the more independent, knowledgeable, and skilled classes of their native country. Their union on the soil of America at once presented the singular phenomenon of a society containing neither lords nor common people, neither rich nor poor. These men possessed, in proportion to their number, a greater mass of intelligence than is to be found in any European nation of our own time. All, without a single exception, _________.
questionText: Which choice most logically completes the text?

A.text: had received a good education, and many of them were known in Europe for their talents and their acquirements.
A.html:
A
had received a good education, and many of them were known in Europe for their talents and their acquirements.
A

B.text: belonged to the aristocracy and thus had been provided with the best tutors and instructors.
B.html:
B
belonged to the aristocracy and thus had been provided with the best tutors and instructors.
B

C.text: had been either indentured servants in Europe or had been poor, so the New World offered them the opportunity to escape a life of servitude.
C.html:
C
had been either indentured servants in Europe or had been poor, so the New World offered them the opportunity to escape a life of servitude.
C

D.text: had a natural affinity for the menial jobs required by the new settlements and put their physical prowess to good use as they attempted to carve a home out of the wilderness.
D.html:
D
had a natural affinity for the menial jobs required by the new settlements and put their physical prowess to good use as they attempted to carve a home out of the wilderness.
D

explanation: A. Choice A most logically completes the text. It follows that the more independent, knowledgeable, and skilled classes would have received a better education and have talents and acquirements. Choice B is clearly contradicted by the text: neither lords nor common people. Choice C is also contradicted by the text: neither rich nor poor. Choice D sounds like it could be true, but no evidence in the text indicates they had a natural affinity for menial jobs or physical prowess.
fullHtml:
The following text is adapted from Democracy in America by Alexis de Tocqueville (1835).

The settlers who established themselves on the shores of New England all belonged to the more independent, knowledgeable, and skilled classes of their native country. Their union on the soil of America at once presented the singular phenomenon of a society containing neither lords nor common people, neither rich nor poor. These men possessed, in proportion to their number, a greater mass of intelligence than is to be found in any European nation of our own time. All, without a single exception, _________.

passageHtml:
The following text is an excerpt from A Brief History of the Olympic Games by David C. Young (Wiley).

"Victory by speed of foot is honored above all." Those are the words of Xenophanes, a 6th century B.c.e. philosopher who objected to athletes and their popularity. The phrase "speed of foot" may recall the words expressed in Homer's Odyssey stressing the glory which an athlete may win "with his hands or with his feet." The shortest foot race, the stade, was one length of the stadium track, the practical equivalent of our 200-meter dash (actually, only 192.27 meters at Olympia, the site of the original Olympic games). Greek tradition held that this 200-meter race was the first and only event held at the first Olympiad in 776 B.c.e.
passageText: The following text is an excerpt from A Brief History of the Olympic Games by David C. Young (Wiley)."Victory by speed of foot is honored above all." Those are the words of Xenophanes, a 6th century B.c.e. philosopher who objected to athletes and their popularity. The phrase "speed of foot" may recall the words expressed in Homer's Odyssey stressing the glory which an athlete may win "with his hands or with his feet." The shortest foot race, the stade, was one length of the stadium track, the practical equivalent of our 200-meter dash (actually, only 192.27 meters at Olympia, the site of the original Olympic games). Greek tradition held that this 200-meter race was the first and only event held at the first Olympiad in 776 B.c.e.
questionText: Which of the following best states the purpose of the quotations in the text?

A.html:
A
To offer conflicting opinions
A

B.html:
B
To establish an authoritative tone
B

C.text: To invite the reader to conduct further research
C.html:
C
To invite the reader to conduct further research
C

D.text: To give a sense of Greek literary style
D.html:
D
To give a sense of Greek literary style
D

explanation: B. Choice B is the best choice because the quotations in the text establish an authoritative tone; they use the words of well-known Greek philosophers to support the content. Choice A is incorrect because the quotations do not conflict with the evidence. Choice C is incorrect because the text doesn't imply that more research is wanted or needed. Choice D is incorrect because the quotations are too short to give a sense of Greek literary style, and they are included to suggest that the evidence of the historical context adds authority to the informative text.

"Victory by speed of foot is honored above all." Those are the words of Xenophanes, a 6th century B.c.e. philosopher who objected to athletes and their popularity. The phrase "speed of foot" may recall the words expressed in Homer's Odyssey stressing the glory which an athlete may win "with his hands or with his feet." The shortest foot race, the stade, was one length of the stadium track, the practical equivalent of our 200-meter dash (actually, only 192.27 meters at Olympia, the site of the original Olympic games). Greek tradition held that this 200-meter race was the first and only event held at the first Olympiad in 776 B.c.e.

passageHtml:
The following passage is adapted from the Library of the Best American Literature, by William W. Birdsall and Rufus M. Jones (1897).

As a poet Poe ranks among the most original in the world. He is preeminently a poet of the imagination. He brings into his poetry all the weirdness, subtlety, artistic detail and facility in coloring which give the charm to his prose stories, and to these he adds a musical flow of language which has never been equalled. To him poetry was music, and there was no poetry that was not musical. For poetic harmony he has had no equal certainly in America, if, indeed, in the world. Admirers of his poems are almost sure to read them over and over again, each time finding new forms of beauty or charm in them, and the reader abandons himself to a current of melodious fancy that soothes and charms like distant music at night, or the rippling of a nearby, but unseen, brook. As one of his biographers has written, __________
passageText: The following passage is adapted from the Library of the Best American Literature, by William W. Birdsall and Rufus M. Jones (1897).As a poet Poe ranks among the most original in the world. He is preeminently a poet of the imagination. He brings into his poetry all the weirdness, subtlety, artistic detail and facility in coloring which give the charm to his prose stories, and to these he adds a musical flow of language which has never been equalled. To him poetry was music, and there was no poetry that was not musical. For poetic harmony he has had no equal certainly in America, if, indeed, in the world. Admirers of his poems are almost sure to read them over and over again, each time finding new forms of beauty or charm in them, and the reader abandons himself to a current of melodious fancy that soothes and charms like distant music at night, or the rippling of a nearby, but unseen, brook. As one of his biographers has written, __________
questionText: Which of the following quotations most logically and effectively completes the text?

A.text: I never heard a voice so musical as his. It was full of the sweetest melody. No one who heard his recitation of the 'Raven' will ever forget the beauty and pathos with which this recitation was rendered.
A.html:
A
I never heard a voice so musical as his. It was full of the sweetest melody. No one who heard his recitation of the 'Raven' will ever forget the beauty and pathos with which this recitation was rendered.
A

B.text: The images which he creates are vague and illusive.
B.html:
B
The images which he creates are vague and illusive.
B

C.text: The artful ingenuity with which he works up the details of his plot, and minute attention to the smallest illustrative particular, give his tales a vivid interest from which no reader can escape.
C.html:
C
The artful ingenuity with which he works up the details of his plot, and minute attention to the smallest illustrative particular, give his tales a vivid interest from which no reader can escape.
C

D.text: The scenes of gloom and terror which he loves to depict, the forms of horror to which he gives almost actual life, render his mastery over the reader most exciting and absorbing.
D.html:
D
The scenes of gloom and terror which he loves to depict, the forms of horror to which he gives almost actual life, render his mastery over the reader most exciting and absorbing.
D

explanation: A. Choice A is the quotation that most logically and effectively completes the text. The focus of the content is Poe's musical flow of language. The text mentions poetic harmony, melodious fancy, and distant music at night, all descriptions of the musical quality of Poe's writing. Thus, Choice A logically follows the text. While the other choices do describe Poe's writing, only Choice A directly references the musical quality of his writing.

As one of his biographers has written, __________

passageHtml:
The following passage is adapted from A Practical Guide to Scientific Data Analysis by David J. Livingstone (Wiley-Blackwell).

Statistics is often concerned with the treatment of a small number of samples which have been drawn from a much larger population. Each of these samples may be described by one or more variables which have been measured or calculated for that sample. For each variable there exists a population of samples. It is the properties of populations of variables that allow the assignment of probabilities, for example, __________
passageText: The following passage is adapted from A Practical Guide to Scientific Data Analysis by David J. Livingstone (Wiley-Blackwell).Statistics is often concerned with the treatment of a small number of samples which have been drawn from a much larger population. Each of these samples may be described by one or more variables which have been measured or calculated for that sample. For each variable there exists a population of samples. It is the properties of populations of variables that allow the assignment of probabilities, for example, __________
questionText: Which choice completes the text with the most logical example?

A.text: all the characteristics of the sample that remain constant throughout the population.
A.html:
A
all the characteristics of the sample that remain constant throughout the population.
A

B.text: the total number of a population from which the samples have been chosen.
B.html:
B
the total number of a population from which the samples have been chosen.
B

C.text: the likelihood that the variable will fall into a particular range and the assessment of significance.
C.html:
C
the likelihood that the variable will fall into a particular range and the assessment of significance.
C

D.text: the exact number of all the occurrences of a particular set of circumstances within a population.
D.html:
D
the exact number of all the occurrences of a particular set of circumstances within a population.
D

explanation: C. Choice C completes the text with the most logical example; the correct answer must be an example of a variable that allows the assignment of probability. Choice A is incorrect because the characteristics of the sample that remain constant are not variables. Choice B is incorrect for the same reason: the total number of a population is not a variable that allows the assignment of probability. Choice D can be eliminated for the same reason: there is no assignment of probability.
